annotation.TEXT: And of course, don't do what I did by risking it. Either way, it's time to move on to Jet Man's stage. This is easily one of the more annoying levels in the demo so far (if partly due to the blaring MIDI music). It's incredibly drawn out due to having several Rush Jet segments, most of which don't need to be here and/or last for about one screen before ending.

Since I wasn't able to show off this stage in the first segment, I'll start with Brick Man for this one. This particular stage has a lot of moving platforms, the same type from the intro stage that you can clip off of and fall to your death (despite clearly landing on them). Then again, this stage also demonstrates that this isn't the only thing wrong with these platforms...

The lightning bolts deal just as much (if not, even more) damage when compared to the red clouds and plasma spheres from the previous segment. You can probably cheese this part with the Time/Flash Stopper, but either way, this section thankfully doesn't last too long.

Aside from having a rather bizarre choice in music, Balloon Man's stage is one of the few in the game with actual gimmicks (aside from the typical moving platforms and springs). The wind in this level will continually push you upwards, usually right into the red clouds (which deal a ton of damage if you touch them). It doesn't help that you can't really stop yourself once you're in the wind, and you'll actually rise up faster if you jump into them.

This screen demonstrates another problem with these platforms. Any time they move on a set path and make an abrupt turn in direction, Mega Man actually bounces slightly as the platform changes its course (or he can get shifted slightly to the left or the right). Not only can this throw off a potential jump you need to make, but I suspect this also has something to do with the aforementioned clipping issues.

Uhh...Don't ask (your guess on why that enemy even exists is just as good as mine). In any case, it's time to show off Rush's Super Adapter. This version doesn't have any of the functions from the ones found in MM6 and 7, but it still has a useful trait to it. Mainly, it lets you run faster and jump higher. Your slide also gets replaced with a dash, which can further increase your speed and allow you to dash-jump (provided you time it right, considering it's a bit finicky).

Shaman Man and his stage seem to be based on aspects from World of Warcraft (having never played WoW myself, I'm mainly going off of quick research and info from people who actually do play it). It's the most incomplete stage in the demo so far: There are only two enemies, and most of the level itself is quite barren. There are a few buildings you can enter, but as far as I can tell, there's nothing in them for now.

From what I've seen, these turrets are completely invincible. If you just run by them without stopping, they usually won't be able to get a shot on you (and even if they do, their damage output is rather low).

Nunchaku Man himself is one of the few note-worthy bosses in this game, if only due to his absurd damage output. I don't think it's from contact damage with him, but rather, it seems to be from his melee attacks. Either way, getting up close to him to use the Top Spin is actually quite dangerous. Unless you have full life (or if you drain a bit of his first), stand back until you're absolutely sure you can finish him off.

Time for more weird enemies. Much like the last one, this is the only stage they show up in - and they only spawn in one specific section. It took me a moment to realize it, but apparently they don't spawn if you're in a Super Adapter form (why this is, I have no idea).

Nunchaku Man's stage doesn't have much in it, aside from several spring and vine sections that make up a majority of the level. These can get tiresome pretty fast, especially considering the springs can act finicky while launching you. If you press certain buttons during your rolling animation, it seems like you can immediately cancel out of your launch and somehow lose every bit of momentum you just had. I assume this is to help with really obnoxious hazard placement (such as the spiked ceilings), but that alone makes me further question the stage design.

As you can see, some of them tend to move rather slow. While this can be a good thing at some points (mostly to help you set up a jump with the rather floaty controls), I'd say it's a better idea to use Beat and Tango's Super Adapters to get by these quicker. Tango's fusion form doesn't have much in the way of powerful or interesting attacks, but it does allow you to climb up walls and jump from them, making it very useful for bypassing certain sections.
